content: The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002 is also known as the "Corporate Fraud Accountability Act." It includes provisions for higher maximum penalties for mail and wire fraud. The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002 increases penalties for mail and wire fraud, amending relevant sections of the United States Code to raise the maximum penalty from five to twenty years. Additionally, a new section on securities fraud is added to Chapter 63 of title 18, targeting schemes to defraud individuals in connection with securities registered under specific acts. The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002 enhances penalties for securities fraud, targeting fraudulent schemes related to securities registered under specific acts. Offenders face fines, imprisonment up to 25 years, or both. The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002 increases penalties for securities fraud, focusing on fraudulent schemes involving securities registered under specific acts. Offenders may be fined, imprisoned for up to 25 years, or both. SEC. 3 addresses tampering with records or obstructing an official proceeding. SEC. 5. DEBTS NONDISCHARGEABLE IF INCURRED IN VIOLATION OF SECURITIES FRAUD LAWS. Section 523(a) of title 11, United States Code, is amended to include a new paragraph (19) regarding claims for violations of Federal securities laws, State securities laws, or related regulations. The amendment to Section 523(a) of title 11, United States Code, includes a new paragraph (19) addressing claims for violations of Federal or State securities laws, common law fraud, deceit, or manipulation in connection with the purchase or sale of securities. This amendment covers claims resulting from judgments, orders, consent orders, decrees, or settlement agreements in Federal or State judicial or administrative proceedings. SEC. 6. CORPORATE RESPONSIBILITY FOR FINANCIAL REPORTS. Amends Chapter 63 of title 18, United States Code by adding a new section requiring corporate officers to certify financial reports filed with the Securities Exchange Commission. The new section added to Chapter 63 of title 18, United States Code requires corporate officers to certify financial reports filed with the Securities Exchange Commission. The statement must certify that the financial statements accurately represent the issuer's operations and financial condition. Criminal penalties are imposed for knowingly or willfully violating this section, with fines up to $5,000,000 and imprisonment up to 20 years. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to grant temporary freeze authority to the Securities and Exchange Commission during lawful investigations involving possible violations of federal securities laws by publicly traded securities issuers or related individuals. The Securities and Exchange Commission can petition a Federal district court for a temporary order to escrow extraordinary payments to persons involved with a publicly traded issuer for 45 days. AUTHORITY OF THE COMMISSION TO PROHIBIT PERSONS FROM SERVING AS OFFICERS OR DIRECTORS. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 allows the Commission to prohibit individuals who have violated certain regulations from serving as officers or directors of registered issuers. The Securities Act of 1933 and the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 empower the Commission to bar individuals who have violated regulations from acting as officers or directors of registered issuers.
